Award.AwardTitle: Synthesis of Sustainable Polymers by Silylium-Catalyzed Polymerization of Renewable Feedstocks
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Eugene Chen of Colorado State University will develop highly reactive, self-healing silylium catalysts and related main-group frustrated Lewis pairs for the synthesis of sustainable stereoregular and optically active polymers from renewable feedstocks. The proposed research seeks to accomplish three important project goals. First, chiral silylium catalysts will be developed that will enable site-controlled synthesis of stereoregular and optically active sustainable polymers. Second, counteranion studies will be employed to render high-speed and stereoselective polymerization by silylium catalysts. Third, the novel Lewis pair polymerizations mediated by silylium and isoelectronic alane-based Lewis pairs will be investigated as a new technique for sustainable polymer synthesis. The broader impacts of this research involve training graduate and undergraduate students, enhancing research infrastructure by bringing together an experimentalist-theoretician collaborative group, and heightening society's awareness of the roles that chemists can play in promoting the development and use of bio-derived raw materials

Plastics are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. At present, plastics are derived predominantly from petroleum based resources and the majority of the commercial catalysts are based on transition metals. This research focuses on developing efficient alternatives to metal catalysts and new synthetic routes into technologically important or advanced plastics using bio-derived feedstocks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central objective of the project was to develop highly reactive, self-healing silylium catalysts and related main-group frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) for the synthesis of sustainable polymers from renewable feedstocks. Macromolecular materials are essential to modern life and the global economy. At present, synthetic polymers are derived predominantly from petroleum-based resources and the majority of the commercial polymerization catalysts are based on transition metals. This research focused on developing new main-group catalysts, specifically cationic organosilicon and isoelectronic neutral organoaluminum catalysts, which can be utilized for the synthesis of technologically important or advanced polymer materials using renewable feedstocks.

Centering on this project’s central objective, our studies have yielded the following five significant project results. First, classical phosphine (P)–borane (B) adducts unexpectedly promote the highly active Lewis pair polymerization (LPP). The P and B site cooperativity is essential for achieving effective polymerization, as shown by this study that has examined the reactivity of a library of P/B Lewis pairs, regulated by steric, electronic, and spatial controls, towards polymerization of a renewable acrylic monomer. Second, the mechanisms of chain initiation, propagation and termination pathways of the LPP of conjugated polar alkenes by Al(C6F5)3-based FLPs and classical Lewis adducts have been elucidated through comprehensive, combined experimental and theoretical studies on the mechanistic aspects of the polymerization. Third, silylium ions enable unique dual catalysis in catalyzing both 1,4-hydrosilylation of a monomer with a hydrosilane to generate the silyl ketene acetal initiator in situ and subsequent living polymerization of the monomer. Fourth, thermally robust polymeric Lewis adducts are formed rapidly between the poly(N-heterocyclic carbene) Lewis base and the carbon Lewis acid C60, thus providing a convenient and efficient synthesis of C60-containing polymers with an unprecedented level of C60 incorporation (up to 69.3 wt%). The polymeric adduct formation also provides a novel means of controlling the donor and acceptor active layer morphology of importance to the organic/polymer photovoltaic solar cells. Fifth, the super acidity of the unsolvated Al(C6F5)3 enabled isolation of the elusive silane-alane complex [Si–H···Al]. The Janus-like nature of this adduct, coupled with strong silane activation, effects multifaceted frustrated-Lewis-pair-type catalysis, including polymerization of conjugated polar alkenes derived from renewable resources.

Key research findings of this study have been disseminated to the general public through comprehensive review articles, original research papers, and conference presentations before academic, industrial, and international audiences. The current NSF support resulted in the employment, training and education of five students and postdoctoral fellows with needed technical skills for carrying out modern research in chemical science; two of the project trainees belong to an underrepresented group (women).


Last Modified: 08/30/2015
Modified by: Eugene Y Chen
